enables you to specify a geographic area where a particular merchant-calculated shipping method is available or unavailable. Google Checkout applies address filters before sending you a <merchantcalculation-callback> request so that you are not asked to calculate shipping costs for a shipping method that is not actually available.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.CheckoutShoppingCartRequest.AddCarrierCalculatedShippingOption(GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingType,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Create a new Carrier Calculated Shipping Option with the minimum Amount of information needed.
member.param: The Shipping Type to add (This must be unique)
The default cost for the shipping option. The default cost will be assessed if Google's attempt to obtain the carrier's shipping rates fails for any reason.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.CheckoutShoppingCartRequest.AddCarrierCalculatedShippingOption(GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingType,System.Decimal,GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierPickup,System.Decimal,System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new Carrier Calculated Shipping Option with the minimum Amount of information needed.
member.param: The Shipping Type to add (This must be unique)
The default cost for the shipping option. The default cost will be assessed if Google's attempt to obtain the carrier's shipping rates fails for any reason.

The <carrier-pickup> tag specifies how the package will be transferred from the merchant to the shipper. Valid values for this tag are REGULAR_PICKUP, SPECIAL_PICKUP and DROP_OFF. The default value for this tag is DROP_OFF.

The <additional-fixed-charge> tag allows you to specify a fixed charge that will be added to the total cost of an order if the buyer selects the associated shipping option. If you also adjust the calculated shipping cost using the <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag, the fixed charge will be added to the adjusted shipping rate.

The <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag specifies a percentage amount by which a carrier-calculated shipping rate will be adjusted. The tag's value may be positive or negative. For example, if the tag's value is 15, then the carrier's shipping rate will effectively be multiplied by 1.15 to determine the shipping cost presented to the buyer. So, if the carrier shipping rate were $10.00, the adjusted shipping rate would be $11.50 i.e. $10.00 + ($10.00 X 15%). If the <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag value is negative, the calculated shipping rate will be discounted by the specified percentage.

member.name: T:GCheckout.OrderProcessing.ShipItemsRequest
member.summary: the <ship-items> command lets you specify shipping information for one or more items in an order. When you send a <ship-items> request, the shipping information in that request will be appended to the existing shipping records for the specified order.
member.remarks: A Box can only contain one Tracking number. Many Items can fit in a box and one item may by placed in multiple boxes. Because of this, There will be two different ways to code this message. The First way is to Add a Box to the shipment and then add items to it. The Second way is to just add items to the shipment passing in the tracking information.

The default cost for the shipping option. The default cost will be assessed if Google's attempt to obtain the carrier's shipping rates fails for any reason.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierCalculatedShipping.AddShippingOption(GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingType,System.Decimal,GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierPickup,System.Decimal,System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new Carrier Calculated Shipping Option with the minimum Amount of information needed.
member.param: The Shipping Type to add (This must be unique)
The default cost for the shipping option. The default cost will be assessed if Google's attempt to obtain the carrier's shipping rates fails for any reason.

The <carrier-pickup> tag specifies how the package will be transferred from the merchant to the shipper. Valid values for this tag are REGULAR_PICKUP, SPECIAL_PICKUP and DROP_OFF. The default value for this tag is DROP_OFF.

The <additional-fixed-charge> tag allows you to specify a fixed charge that will be added to the total cost of an order if the buyer selects the associated shipping option. If you also adjust the calculated shipping cost using the <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag, the fixed charge will be added to the adjusted shipping rate.

The <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag specifies a percentage amount by which a carrier-calculated shipping rate will be adjusted. The tag's value may be positive or negative. For example, if the tag's value is 15, then the carrier's shipping rate will effectively be multiplied by 1.15 to determine the shipping cost presented to the buyer. So, if the carrier shipping rate were $10.00, the adjusted shipping rate would be $11.50 i.e. $10.00 + ($10.00 X 15%). If the <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag value is negative, the calculated shipping rate will be discounted by the specified percentage.

member.summary: The <shipping-type> tag identifies the shipping option that is being offered to the buyer.

member.name: P:GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierCalculatedShippingOption.CarrierPickup
member.summary: The <carrier-pickup> tag specifies how the package will be transferred from the merchant to the shipper. Valid values for this tag are REGULAR_PICKUP, SPECIAL_PICKUP and DROP_OFF. The default value for this tag is DROP_OFF.

member.name: P:GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierCalculatedShippingOption.AdditionalFixedCharge
member.summary: The <additional-fixed-charge> tag allows you to specify a fixed charge that will be added to the total cost of an order if the buyer selects the associated shipping option. If you also adjust the calculated shipping cost using the <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag, the fixed charge will be added to the adjusted shipping rate.

member.name: P:GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierCalculatedShippingOption.AdditionalVariableChargePercent
member.summary: The <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag specifies a percentage amount by which a carrier-calculated shipping rate will be adjusted. The tag's value may be positive or negative. For example, if the tag's value is 15, then the carrier's shipping rate will effectively be multiplied by 1.15 to determine the shipping cost presented to the buyer. So, if the carrier shipping rate were $10.00, the adjusted shipping rate would be $11.50 i.e. $10.00 + ($10.00 X 15%). If the <additional-variable-charge-percent> tag value is negative, the calculated shipping rate will be discounted by the specified percentage.

member.name: P:GCheckout.Checkout.CarrierCalculatedShippingOption.ShippingOption
member.summary: This is the shipping option created by the internal type It should not be modified outside of this class or it will not be in sync.

member.name: T:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions
member.summary: You can also use the shipping-restrictions element to specify areas where a flat-rate or merchant-calculated shipping option is (or is not) available. Shipping options can be restricted to particular zip codes or zip code ranges, to particular states or to particular areas of the United States.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.AddAllowedWorldArea
member.summary: This tag represents the entire world. This tag has no attributes and does not contain anyother elements.
member.remarks: you can use the <world-area> tag to indicate that a shipping option is available worldwide and then identify specific excluded areas where the shipping option is unavailable. Those excluded areas could identify regions that are covered by other shipping options or regions where you do not ship items.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.AddAllowedPostalArea(System.String)
member.summary: You can use the <postal-area> tag to identify any country in the world, including the United States. You can also specify regions by postal codes.
member.param: This tag contains the two-letter ISO 3166-1 country code for the postal area.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.AddAllowedPostalArea(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: You can use the <postal-area> tag to identify any country in the world, including the United States. You can also specify regions by postal codes.
member.param: This tag contains the two-letter ISO 3166-1 country code for the postal area.

This tag identifies a postal code or a range of postal codes for the postal area. To specify a range of postal codes, use an asterisk as a wildcard operator in the tag's value. For example, you can specify that a shipping option is available for all postal codes beginning with "SW" by entering SW* as the <postal-code-pattern> value.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.AddAllowedZipPattern(System.String)
member.summary: This method adds an allowed zip code pattern to a <us-zip-area> element. The <us-zip-area> element, in turn, appears as a subelement of <allowed-areas>.
member.param: The zip pattern.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.AddAllowedStateCode(System.String)
member.summary: This method adds an allowed U.S. state code to a <us-state-area> element. The <us-state-area> element, in turn, appears as a subelement of <allowed-areas>.
member.param: The state code.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.ShippingRestrictions.AddAllowedCountryArea(GCheckout.AutoGen.USAreas)
member.summary: This method adds an allowed U.S. country area to a <us-country-area> element. The <us-country-area> element, in turn, appears as a subelement of <allowed-areas>.
member.param: The country area.

member.param: This tag contains the two-letter ISO 3166-1 country code for the postal area.

This tag identifies a postal code or a range of postal codes for the postal area. To specify a range of postal codes, use an asterisk as a wildcard operator in the tag's value. For example, you can specify that a shipping option is available for all postal codes beginning with "SW" by entering SW* as the <postal-code-pattern> value.

member.name: T:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode
member.summary: The <mode> tag allows you to specify the methodology that will be used to round values to two decimal places. This tag may contain any of the following values, each of which is defined in the Java 1.5 specification for the RoundingMode enumeration

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.UP
member.summary: This mode rounds numbers away from zero. For example, the number 1.111 would be rounded to 1.12.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.DOWN
member.summary: This mode rounds numbers toward zero. For example, the number 1.666 would be rounded to 1.66.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.CEILING
member.summary: This mode rounds numbers toward positive infinity. For positive numbers, the CEILING mode functions identically to the UP rounding mode. For negative numbers, the CEILING mode functions identically to the DOWN rounding mode.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.FLOOR
member.summary: TODO Not defined in pdf

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.HALF_UP
member.summary: This mode rounds numbers to the nearest digit. However, if the number being rounded is followed by a five and no additional nonzero digits, then then that number will be rounded up. For example, the number 1.165 would be rounded to 1.17.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.HALF_DOWN
member.summary: This mode rounds numbers to the nearest digit. However, if the number being rounded is followed by a five and no additional nonzero digits, then then that number will be rounded down. For example, the number 1.165 would be rounded to 1.16.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.HALF_EVEN
member.summary: HALF_EVEN - This mode, which is also known as banker's rounding, is described earlier in this section. Google Checkout uses HALF_EVEN as its default rounding mode.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingMode.UNNECESSARY
member.summary: TODO Not defined in pdf

member.name: T:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingRule
member.summary: The <rule> tag specifies when rounding rules should be applied to monetary values while Google Checkout is computing an order total. This tag may contain either of the following values:

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingRule.PER_LINE
member.summary: This rounding rule indicates that Google should calculate the tax for each line item and round each of those tax values using the specified rounding mode. After each tax value has been rounded, Google should then add the tax values to determine the total tax.
member.remarks: Note: A line item is comprised of one or more units of the same item. For example, if a shopping cart contains two identical items that each cost $1.00 and the sales tax rate is 7.5 percent, then the total cost of the line item is $2.00 and the total tax for the line item is 15 cents.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.RoundingRule.TOTAL
member.summary: This rounding rule indicates that Google should calculate the tax for each item and add those tax values to calculate the total unrounded tax amount for the order. Google should then apply the specified rounding mode to the total tax to determine the total tax for the order.

member.name: T:GCheckout.Util.StreamWrapper
member.summary: Class used by the Encoder Helper to stop the XmlReader from closing the stream
member.remarks: If the XmlReader throws an exception against a stream, it closes the stream. Since we need to find out what's in the stream, we can't close it. The user may also be using the stream for something. So what we are doing is not allowing the Close method to be called.

will return the string new-order-notification.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Util.EncodeHelper.GetElementValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the value of the first element or attribute in a piece of XML.

Name of the element or attribute to search for.
member.returns: The value of the first element or attribute. If there is no such element or attribute in the XML, an empty string is returned.
member.example:
Assume the string variable Xml has this value:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <new-order-notification xmlns="http://checkout.google.com/schema/2" serial-number="85f54628-538a-44fc-8605-ae62364f6c71"> <google-order-number>841171949013218</google-order-number> ... </new-order-notification>
Calling GetElementValue(Xml, "google-order-number") will return 841171949013218. Calling GetElementValue(Xml, "serial-number") will return 85f54628-538a-44fc-8605-ae62364f6c71.

member.name: T:GCheckout.Checkout.DisplayDisposition
member.summary: The <display-disposition> tag specifies when the buyer will be able to access purchased digital content. The only valid values for this tag are OPTIMISTIC and PESSIMISTIC.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.DisplayDisposition.Pessimistic
member.summary: If the value of the <display-disposition> tag is PESSIMISTIC, the buyer cannot access purchased digital content until his credit card has been authorized to be charged for the amount of the order.

member.name: F:GCheckout.Checkout.DisplayDisposition.Optimistic
member.summary: If the value of the <display-disposition> tag is OPTIMISTIC, then Google will display instructions for accessing the digital content as soon as the buyer confirms the order. We recommend that you only use optimistic delivery if you can easily revoke access to the digital content if Google cannot authorize the customer's credit card.

member.name: P:GCheckout.Checkout.BuyerMessages.IncludeGiftReceipt
member.summary: If your API request includes the <include-gift-receipt> tag and the tag's value is true, then Google Checkout will indicate that a gift receipt will be included with the order. The buyer will have the option of removing the gift receipt from the order before completing the purchase.

member.summary: Create a new Alternate Tax Table

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.AlternateTaxTable.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Create a new Alternate Tax Table
member.param: The name attribute value contains a string that can be used to identify a tax table or shipping method. The attribute value must be at least one non-space character and may not be longer than 255 characters.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.AlternateTaxTable.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a new Alternate Tax Table
member.param: The name attribute value contains a string that can be used to identify a tax table or shipping method. The attribute value must be at least one non-space character and may not be longer than 255 characters.

The standalone attribute indicates how taxes should be calculated if there is no matching alternate-tax-rule for the given state, zip code or country area. If this attribute's value is TRUE and there is no matching alternate-tax-rule, the tax amount will be zero. If the attribute's value is FALSE and there is no matching alternate-tax-rule, the tax amount will be calculated using the default tax table.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.AlternateTaxTable.AddStateTaxRule(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: This method adds a tax rule associated with a particular state.
member.param: This parameter contains a two-letter U.S. state code associated with a tax rule.
The tax rate associated with a tax rule. Tax rates are expressed as decimal values. For example, a value of 0.0825 specifies a tax rate of 8.25%.

member.name: M:GCheckout.Checkout.AlternateTaxTable.AddPostalAreaTaxRule(System.String,System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Adds the country tax rule. This method adds a tax rule associated with a particular state.
member.param: Required. This tag contains the two-letter ISO 3166-1 country code for the postal area.

Optional. This tag identifies a postal code or a range of postal codes for the postal area. To specify a range of postal codes, use an asterisk as a wildcard operator in the tag's value. For example, you can specify that a shipping option is available for all postal codes beginning with "SW" by entering SW* as the <postal-code-pattern> value.
The tax rate associated with a tax rule. Tax rates are expressed as decimal values. For example, a value of 0.0825 specifies a tax rate of 8.25%.
